Comment: You are a doctor even if you don't do residency.   There are cases where people can operate without residency in certain moonlighting positions. But it's not so common.   Casey Means is a doctor who has genuinely been trying to make people healthier. She's got a book and all.   I'm not so sure what's the big deal. She dropped out of her surgical residency. Those can be 7 yrs long.
Author: pickledplumber

Comment: This is kinda true in like Mississippi and some programs for foreign medical grads. Many of which have completed specialization training outside the US. While technically it’s possible if you treat anyone and use the title Dr without holding a license, you are definitely operating illegally unless someone is supervising you. Also moonlighting requires a license, never heard of any moonlighting gig that would let people with degrees and no licenses to work, or the country would be filled with international grads that are locked out due to limited residency positions.   No license means no real consequences to her actions. So who is willing to put their license on the line and supervise her

Author: pickledplumber

Comment: So all doctors have an internship here which they essentially go around to all the different fields trying things. The last two years of medical school are spent in the hospital doing direct patient care   I think it's pretty ridiculous to say that because you didn't complete residency, you don't have experience with patients. That's not how the US medical system works. In fact, the last 2 years of medical school, internship year or years and the beginning of residency is where you gain your experience dealing with patients.   Especially given that she was a surgery resident. She would have worked with other residents to come up with treatment plans and propose them to their attendings. It's literally what they do every week. The learning is in the doing.

Comment: I know, I went through it. As did my classmates and my friends, and coworkers. Nobody would agree we know the healthcare system until we are out on our own facing the responsibilities of our actions treating patients on our own.   I don’t really need it explained to me, I know what the limitations of stopping would be at any step along the way to a full license. And no, the answer isn’t because I was a bad student or anything, you really can’t know what that responsibility feels like without practice, and then to tell other people how they should practice when you haven’t done so yourself is beyond comprehension. I would not be at all inclined to tell an engineer how something should be engineered just because my undergrad degree was in engineering. I never worked as one, and I can give my opinion but should leave the engineering to the real engineers working that field everyday, of which I am not
